journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Repair of Meniscal Tears Associated With Tibial Plateau Fractures
title-group.subtitle: A Review of 15 Cases

article-meta.aff: †Arthroscopic Surgery Unit, Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Hospital Ramón y Cajal, Madrid, Spain
‡Department of Anesthesiology, Hospital Ramón y Cajal, Madrid, Spain
§Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Hospital Maz, Zaragoza, Spain
Investigation performed at Hospital Ramón y Cajal, Madrid, Spain

author-notes.corresp: *Miguel Ángel Ruiz-Ibán, MD, PhD, Unidad de Cirugía Artroscópica, Departamento de COT, Hospital Ramón y Cajal, Cta Colmenar Km 9.100, Madrid 28034, Spain (e-mail: drmri@hotmail.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Tibial plateau fractures are frequently associated with meniscal tears. Little is known about the results of meniscal repair in this group of patients.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To determine the results of repair of meniscal tears found during arthroscopically assisted reduction and internal fixation (ARIF) of tibial plateau fractures.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: In a cohort of 51 tibial plateau fractures treated with ARIF, 15 associated meniscal tears (15 knees) in 14 patients were repaired. There were 12 peripheral longitudinal tears of the lateral meniscus, 1 longitudinal peripheral tear of the medial meniscus, 1 full-thickness radial tear of the lateral meniscus, and 1 bird-beak tear of the lateral meniscus. Repairs were performed using an outside-in technique for the anterior horn and all-inside repair for the body and posterior horn lesions. Mean (SD) age at operation was 47.3 (14.0) years. Patients were followed for a mean (SD) of 4.83 (1.01) years and evaluated using the Rasmussen, Honkonen, Lysholm, Tegner, and International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores. A second-look arthroscopy was performed in 13 knees a mean (SD) of 14.2 (10.1) months after the initial surgery.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The mean (SD) Rasmussen score was 29.1 (0.96). Thirteen of 15 patients scored good or excellent results in all Honkonen sections. The mean (SD) Lysholm score was 88.6 (12.4). The mean (SD) IKDC score was 79.3 (19.3). There was a small decrease of the activity level according to the Tegner score when compared with the preoperative situation (1.20 [1.82], P = .022). There were not any meniscal symptoms in any case. Of the 13 menisci evaluated with second-look arthroscopy, 12 had healed completely and a radial tear had healed partially in the vascular zone. In one of the cases that healed, a new tear was found in a different location.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Meniscal repair of tears associated with tibial plateau fractures has good results. All patients had good or excellent clinical results. Second-look arthroscopy confirmed complete healing in 92% of meniscal tears when performed.

body.p: Tibial plateau fractures are common intra-articular fractures that can cause significant disability.7,9,25 The use of arthroscopic techniques to control reduction accurately (arthroscopic reduction and internal fixation, ARIF) is widespread,6,26,28 even in complex fractures.7,8 Intraoperative arthroscopic evaluation allows for the diagnosis of associated intra-articular lesions and helps with their management.

Meniscal tears are found in 36% to 47% of tibial plateau fractures.13,21,27,40 As meniscectomy has a deleterious effect on the knee in the long term,17,30,32 especially when there are associated chondral lesions, meniscal repair should be considered for meniscal lesions associated with tibial plateau fractures. Unfortunately, there is little information about the outcome of these repairs in this group of patients as these are not reported separately.

The objective of this study was to retrospectively review a subset of patients from an ongoing prospective study of patients with tibial plateau fractures with associated meniscal tears that had been repaired during the initial ARIF procedure and evaluate the clinical results and morphological results with arthroscopic second-look examination.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This is a retrospective review of a subset of patients included in a cohort study with prospective data collection and evaluation. This study was approved by the local institutional review board.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: In January 2004, the lead author’s institution started a prospective study of patients who had sustained tibial plateau fractures to evaluate the efficacy of surgical treatment with ARIF in the long term. Until March 2008, a total of 51 tibial plateau fractures in 50 patients were surgically treated with ARIF by a single surgeon. In 33 knees, an associated lesion was present. A total of 22 meniscal tears were found (19 lateral, 3 medial, in 21 knees). Of these, 4 were considered stable (according to the criteria defined by Easly et al11), and 3 were complex lesions that were considered inadequate for repairing and were resected (1 large amputated bucket-handle tear of the lateral meniscus, 1 large bird-beak lateral meniscal tear with significant meniscal contusion, and 1 degenerative central tear of the medial meniscus). In 15 menisci (15 knees, 14 patients, 13 lateral and 2 medial), the lesions were considered suitable to repair. The epidemiological characteristics, tibial plateau fracture type, associated lesions, and treatment type of the full tibial plateau group and of the patients in which a meniscal repair was performed can be seen in Table 1. A description of the meniscal lesions in the patients where a repair was performed can be seen in Table 2.

caption.p: Description of the Complete Tibial Plateau Fracture Group and the Meniscal Repair Groupa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Age is expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Numbers in parentheses are percentages of total knees in each group. Abbreviations: ACL, anterior cruciate ligament; MCL, medial collateral ligament; PCL, posterior cruciate ligament; PLC, posterior ligamentous complex.

caption.p: Description of the Cases in Which a Meniscal Repair Was Performeda

fn.label: a
fn.p: The location (AH, anterior horn; B, body; MC, meniscocapsular junction; PH, posterior horn; RR, red-red zone) and type (BB, bird beak; L, longitudinal; R, radial) of meniscal tear are presented. The type and number of sutures used are also presented (FF, fast fix; HM, horizontal mattress; OI, outside-in with nonabsorbable sutures; V, vertical).

fn.label: b
fn.p: Case 3 and 4 are the same patient with bilateral fractures.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Associated degenerative medial meniscal tear that was partially resected.

sec.title: Surgical Treatment
sec.p: The 14 patients (15 meniscal repairs; 1 patient had bilateral tibial plateau fractures with bilateral lateral menisci tears) were admitted through the emergency room (ER) department. After initial evaluation with anteroposterior and lateral x-ray projections and a neurovascular examination, a 3-dimensional computed tomography (CT) scan was performed and surgery was scheduled as available (range, 0-7 days). The patients were also questioned about their preoperative activity level using the Tegner activity score (TAS).38

The patients were operated under spinal anesthesia with the knee flexed and hanging over the table so as to allow free movement and auxiliary evaluation with intraoperative C-Arm radiology. An examination of the knee under anesthesia allowed for a more precise ligamentous examination. The procedure started with a diagnostic arthroscopy and a thorough lavage of the articular hematoma. No pump was used. After diagnosis of the precise configuration of the articular fracture according to the Schatzker classification and the associated articular lesions, the tibial plateau fracture was managed first. The osseous fragments were reduced and internal fixation was performed with compression screws in all patients. In most Schatzker type 4 and 5 and in all type 6 fractures, an additional percutaneous buttress plate was used.

All meniscal tears were initially considered for repair. The meniscal repair was performed after internal fixation of the fracture. Usually, the affected meniscus was over the most comminuted part of the articular fracture, and leaving it unrepaired allowed for a clearer view of the articular fragments. The meniscal repair was performed using a combination of all-inside repair with outside-in sutures. An all-inside device (Fastfix; Smith & Nephew, Andover, Massachusetts) was used to repair the body and posterior horn of the meniscus with vertical and horizontal stitches. The anterior horn was repaired using an outside-inside technique with mattress stitches with 2/0 polydioxanone absorbable sutures (PDS; Ethicon, Somerville, New Jersey). The details of the repair in each case are shown in Table 2.

sec.title: Postoperative Management
sec.p: The patients were instructed to be nonweightbearing for 8 weeks, and full weightbearing was allowed after 12 weeks. For the first 3 weeks after surgery, the patients used an articulated brace with range of motion limited from 0° to 90° of flexion. In the first postoperative week, a physical therapy program was started that included therapy and education 3 days a week for at least 6 weeks and until a range of motion of 0° to 140° was obtained. Initial emphasis was placed on obtaining early full extension.

sec.title: Evaluation Protocols
sec.p: The patients were evaluated according to the protocols established in the cohort study: radiological controls were performed 1 day, 3 and 6 weeks after surgery, and every 6 weeks thereafter until consolidation was achieved. A full clinical evaluation was performed 1 and 2 years after surgery and every 2 years thereafter. The evaluation included a standard knee evaluation protocol with meniscal and ligamentous tests, a 2-projection radiograph (anteroposterior and lateral standing radiographs), and an evaluation according to the Rasmussen clinical score,31 Honkonen score,14 Lysholm score,24 TAS, and International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) subjective questionnaire.18 The radiographs were evaluated according to the Honkonen score criteria.14 The IKDC data were adjusted for age and sex using the data obtained by Anderson et al.2

When a second-look arthroscopy was performed, the integrity of the meniscal repair was assessed using an arthroscopic probe, and the chondral surface of the knee compartments was evaluated, using the International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) classification.20
The statistical analysis was performed with SPSS version 10 (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois). A Student t test for paired data was used for the TAS.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 15 tibial plateau fractures, the lateral plateau was affected in 12 knees (8 Schatzker type 2 fractures, 3 Schatzker type 1 fractures, and 1 Schatzker type 3 fracture), the medial plateau in 1 knee (Schatzker type 4 fracture), and both plateaus in 2 knees (2 Schatzker type 5 fractures). An anatomic reduction of the articular fragments (less than 1 mm displacement) was obtained in all cases. One patient (case 1, a 69-year-old woman) had grade II diffuse degenerative changes in the cartilage of the medial compartment and grade II changes in the lateral and femoropatellar compartment. No early postoperative complications appeared, and the 15 patients were discharged after a mean (SD) of 3.43 (2.28) days. No patient was lost from follow-up. Nine patients were evaluated after 4 years, and 6 patients were evaluated after 6 years with a mean (SD) follow-up of 4.83 (1.01) years. All tibial plateau fractures had healed radiographically and clinically at the 12-week follow-up. One patient (case 2) developed arthrofibrosis with a range of motion of 10° to 80° at 5 months postoperatively, and arthroscopic arthrolysis and mobilization under anesthesia was performed. The patient regained a functional range of motion (0°-145°).

At the latest follow-up, none of the 15 patients had clinical symptoms related to meniscal injury such as catching, locking, or pain in hyperflexion, and the meniscal tests were negative. Radiographic evaluation showed minor degenerative changes in 4 cases. The results from the evaluation protocols for each case can be seen in Table 3. All patients had excellent results on the Rasmussen scale. Only 2 patients scored “fair” in any of the categories of the Honkonen scale, and 8 scored “excellent” in all categories. According to the Lysholm score,24 9 knees had an excellent result, 4 had a good result, 1 had a fair result, and 1 had a poor result. When the adjusted IKDC score was calculated, 2 patients scored below the normal range of activity for patients of their age and sex. The patients presented a slight decrease in the level of sporting activity as defined by the TAS when compared with the preoperative situation (a decrease of 1.20 [1.82] points, P = .022).

tr.td: Lateral femoral condyle 1-cm2 ICRS II lesions
Lateral tibial plateau 2-cm2 ICRS II lesions

fn.label: a
fn.p: The International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score is adjusted for age and sex, and the percentile in which the patient is located is displayed (more is better, with 50 meaning that function is in the median of a population of same age and sex and healthy knees). For the Honkonen score, E indicates excellent; G, good; and F, fair. The chondral lesions were noted according to their size and International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) classification; discrete grade I lesions at the level of the fracture site were considered normal. Abbreviations: NA, not available; TAS, Tegner activity score.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Associated arthroscopic arthrolysis and mobilization performed in second look.

fn.label: c
fn.p: The radial tear had healed peripherally, but the central third was still torn and was resected.

fn.label: d
fn.p: The peripheral lesion healed; a different small central degenerative posterior horn lesion was resected.

sec.p: In 13 knees, a second-look arthroscopy was performed, and the result of the meniscal repair was directly assessed. In all patients, an associated hardware removal of the screws was performed at the same time. In case 2, the arthroscopic evaluation was performed during the arthrolysis procedure. In cases 1 and 10, the patient had mild articular pain that on examination seemed unrelated to meniscal injury, but an arthroscopy was performed to assess the articular surface. In the other 10 knees, the diagnostic arthroscopy was performed as a secondary procedure during hardware removal under spinal anesthesia due to discomfort related to the hardware. All patients gave written informed consent for the operation. None of the arthroscopic procedures was performed solely for evaluation of the meniscal tear. The same surgeon performed all arthroscopic procedures.

In 12 of the 13 repaired menisci, the lesions had healed completely. In case 4 (a complete radial tear of the body of the lateral meniscus), the lesion had healed peripherally, but the central third (2-3 mm) was still torn, and a minimal partial (less than 5% of meniscal volume) meniscal resection was performed. In case 10, a small degenerative tear at the inner rim of the posterior horn in the lateral meniscus was observed, and a limited meniscectomy was performed; this lesion seemed to be completely unrelated to the peripheral longitudinal tear that the patient had initially, which was considered to be completely healed.

The chondral surface was evaluated in all cases. There were no changes in the chondral surface of the compartments unaffected by the fracture. In 10 cases, the fracture line was barely visible and filled with a thin line of fibrocartilage; palpation at this level with the probe identified the zone as slightly softer than the intact cartilage, and these lesions were considered minimal ICRS grade I changes. In case 1, the initially observed grade II diffuse degenerative changes in the lateral compartment had not deteriorated. In case 10 (a lateral tibial plateau fractured with a second-look arthroscopy performed 38 months after the initial surgery), grade II changes were observed in a 2-cm2 area situated at the level of the fracture site at the lateral tibial plateau. In case 3 (a lateral tibial plateau fracture with a second-look arthroscopy performed 26 months after the initial surgery), grade II changes were observed in a 1-cm2 area situated at the lateral femoral condyle.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Meniscal tears are common in patients with tibial plateau fractures. Although meniscectomy is an option during the difficult reconstructions that these fractures often need, there is a clear case for meniscal repair: these tears are usually suitable to repair, and these patients may benefit especially from the chondroprotective effect of an intact meniscus.

This study shows that meniscal tears associated with tibial plateau fractures heal satisfactorily when repaired acutely in most cases. Most patients with these lesions have good or excellent clinical results at a mean 5-year follow-up.

The patients reviewed in this study belong to a group of patients with tibial plateau fractures consecutively treated with ARIF. This group is comparable in age and fracture type distribution with other previously published series of fractures treated with ARIF.5,7,13,25,33,34,40 The prevalence of associated lesions was 64.7%, falling in the range of 60% to 70% of other series.7,13,19 The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear rate was 23%, which is similar to the 25% to 48% incidence found by others.1,7,13,21,27 The medial collateral ligament (MCL) had a grade III rupture in 2 patients (3.9%), in a range similar to that observed by others.7,13

The prevalence of meniscal tears was 41.2%, which is similar to the rate found by other authors with ranges between 36% and 61%.1,7,13,21,27 Interestingly, authors not using arthroscopy during surgery usually do not report meniscal tears,23,25,29 suggesting that those may be left untreated. Most lesions occurred in the lateral meniscus (19 of 22), in a similar fashion to those found by Vangsness et al40 (13 of 17) and Kayali et al19 (7 of 10). As expected,19,36,40 all the medial meniscal tears appeared in fractures affecting the medial compartment of the knee (2 Schatzker type 4 fractures and 1 Schatzker type 5 fracture). The repair rate of unstable meniscal tears in this report (15 of 18 unstable menisci, 83.3%) is clearly higher than those reported by Kayali et al19 (only 1 of 10 meniscal tears repaired, 10%), Scheerlinck et al36 (2 of 14 tears, 14%), Vangsness et al40 (6 of 17 menisci repaired, 35%), Rossi et al34 (5 of 13 tears, 38%), Abdel-Hamid et al1 (37 of 56 tears, 66%), or Chan et al7 (15 of 22 tears, 68%). These authors limited repair attempts to peripheral longitudinal lesions at best. Our high repair rate may be explained by a greater awareness of the deleterious effects of meniscectomy by the authors, who are mainly sports surgeons rather than trauma surgeons; it may also be explained in part by the initial good results obtained by the authors, which prompted more confidence in meniscal repair.

The clinical results in the patients who had a meniscal repair can be considered excellent. The Rasmussen clinical score, the traditional scale used for tibial plateau fracture evaluation, proved to be not sensitive enough as all patients scored excellent results. In the Honkonen scale, which evaluates functional, clinical, subjective, and radiological results, 53% scored excellent in all categories, and only 2 patients had a fair result in the functional (1 case) or radiological (1 case) sections. None of the patients showed evidence of joint space narrowing. For the Lysholm score, a good or excellent result was obtained in 13 of 15 cases. The IKDC questionnaire can be adjusted to age and is considered very discriminative in evaluating knee function; 47% of the knees had a function higher than the mean function expected for their age, and only 2 knees performed below the ordinary function expected for the patient age range (less than 5%). The level of sporting activity was evaluated by the TAS, a scale that defines 11 levels of activity, with 11 being the most challenging for the knee (national- or international-level soccer player) and 0 being incapacitated by the knee problem; there was a small but significant decrease in the level of sporting activity. This may not be clinically relevant because, after a mean 5 years of follow-up, the activity level would decrease anyway, and the TAS has been shown to decrease with age.4

There are no comparable data in the literature as the reported series do not give specific results for the meniscal repair groups, so comparisons can only be made with data referred to general groups of tibial plateau fractures. Chan et al7 treated arthroscopically 44 Schatzker type 1 to 5 fractures and followed them for 6.8 years; according to the Rasmussen score, they obtained excellent results in 41 (93%) patients, 2 good results, and 1 fair result; joint space narrowing was observed in 19% of patients. Scheerlinck et al36 treated arthroscopically 33 AO type B1 to C1 fractures and followed them for 5.2 years with the Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) score. They obtained excellent results in 26 (78.8%) patients, 5 good results, and 2 fair results and found joint space narrowing in 11 of 38 patients. Rossi et al34 treated arthroscopically 46 Schatzker type 2 and 3 fractures and followed them for a mean of 5.2 years; patients obtained a mean (SD) Rasmussen score of 28.2 (1.4) and had an 8.6% rate of osteoarthritis. Our results seem to be at least as good if not better than those presented by these authors.

Of the 15 meniscal repairs, 13 were evaluated by second-look arthroscopy. All 12 longitudinal peripheral tears healed completely, and 1 radial lateral meniscal tear healed partially. These results compare favorably with those obtained by other authors when second-look arthroscopy was used as an evaluation tool. When analyzing isolated meniscal injuries, the healing rate of peripheral meniscal tears was 56% of 36 torn menisci by Horibe et al15; Scott et al35 found that only 40% of these lesions healed completely, and Tenuta and Arciero39 found that only 8 of 14 healed satisfactorily. When an ACL repair was associated with the repair of a peripheral longitudinal lesion, Tachibana et al37 found complete healing in 74% of 62 meniscal tears, Feng et al12 found full healing in 81% of 67 tears, and Asahina et al3 observed complete healing in 75% of 98 meniscal tears. The partial healing of the radial tear was not unexpected, as more than 60% of these lesions do not heal completely.10 There was 1 case of retear of the meniscus, which seemed to occur in 14% of meniscal repairs.22

The chondral surface on second-look arthroscopy presented minimum changes in 10 of 13 cases that can be attributed to the fracture. One patient had degenerative changes that were apparent in the initial surgery and had not evolved. One patient (case 3) had a small area of grade II degenerative changes in the lateral condyle but otherwise had an excellent clinical outcome. In another patient (case 10), a grade II lesion was present in the lateral plateau; this patient had a clear decrease in his activity level and a low adjusted IKDC score that can be attributed to the chondral lesion.

The high success rate of the meniscal repairs observed in this group of patients with second-look arthroscopy can be attributed to different causes. First, the repair was performed customarily in the first week after the lesion, and acute repair may be of benefit in meniscal healing. Second, the postoperative protocol is quite conservative for a meniscal repair. Third, the local environment is certainly more similar to that found during a concomitant ACL repair (known to improve the healing rate of meniscal tears16,39) than that of an isolated repair, with the fracture site offering ready access to the bone marrow.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The limitations of a case series such as this are evident: there is no control group and no randomization of treatment options. These limitations are difficult to overcome: the patients who had a meniscectomy could have been used as a control group, but there were only 3 of these in our series. Furthermore, planning a randomized controlled trial in which a group is selected for meniscectomy is not an option given the current evidence of its deleterious effects.17,30,32 This study also had a relatively small sample size, although meniscal tears in tibial plateau fractures are not common lesions, and most published series are also small.

A more detailed account of the preinjury activity level of the patients involved would have allowed for a more precise assessment of the functional results at follow-up. Unfortunately, only the TAS was recorded, and this is a limitation of the study.

Another limitation of the study is the relative short follow-up of the patients. Although all patients were followed for at least 4 years, the deleterious effect of the tibial plateau fracture or meniscal tear may not be evident at this time. It should be noted that other authors7,34,36 have found significant joint space narrowing in 9% to 29% of patients with similar follow-up times.
It also would have been ideal to have an arthroscopic second look at all the repaired menisci, but this was performed in only 87% of the knees.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Meniscal repair of tears associated with tibial plateau fractures has good results. All patients had good or excellent clinical results. Second-look arthroscopy confirmed complete healing in 92% of meniscal tears when performed.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
